pillar.title: Education, Research, Knowledge and Innovation
pillar.definition: Training methods, CE, teaching, guidelines, evidence-based practice, clinical research, quality improvement, technology development, AI in anesthesia, theoretical or scientific exploration (including consciousness). This pillar encompasses how anesthesia knowledge is created, evaluated, transmitted, and advanced.
inclusion_tests: Is this about creating, evaluating, or transmitting knowledge?
Is this about how anesthesia professionals are trained or educated?
Is this about research methodology, evidence synthesis, or guideline development?
Is this about innovation pipelines (new drugs, devices, AI, digital health)?
Is this about quality improvement science (QI methods, PDSA, registries)?
Is this about scientific communication (publishing, conferences, dissemination)?
exclusion_tests: Clinical practice, physiology, patient care decisions → Pillar 1
Role definitions, scope boundaries, training requirements (who the provider IS) → Pillar 2
Systems, equipment, OR operations, IT infrastructure → Pillar 3
Legal requirements, compliance, malpractice, ethics statutes → Pillar 4
Compensation mechanics, billing, contracts, business structures → Pillar 5
Career paths, workforce deployment, job transitions, leadership roles → Pillar 7
Burnout, wellbeing, culture, OR politics, professional identity as lived experience → Pillar 8

sub_pillars.title: Education Systems, Programs and Pedagogy
sub_pillars.definition: The architecture, governance, and instructional methods of anesthesia training. This sub-pillar covers program structures (CRNA and physician), accreditation standards, curriculum design, teaching methodologies, adult learning principles, simulation-based education, and the integration of didactic and clinical experiences that produce competent anesthesia providers.

branches.title: Program Architecture, Governance and Accreditation
branches.definition: The structural components of anesthesia training programs including program types (CRNA, physician), duration, degree requirements, governance bodies, accreditation standards (COA, ACGME), and the organizations that oversee educational quality.
branches.lens: Understanding how anesthesia training programs are structured and regulated

branches.title: Curriculum Design and Integration
branches.definition: How anesthesia curricula are developed, organized, and delivered. Includes didactic-clinical integration, rotation structures, spiral curricula, competency mapping, and the alignment of learning objectives with professional practice requirements.
branches.lens: Designing effective learning experiences across the training continuum

branches.title: Teaching Methods and Instructional Design
branches.definition: Pedagogical approaches for anesthesia education including adult learning theory (andragogy), competency-based education, flipped classrooms, case-based and team-based learning, clinical teaching techniques, feedback models, and remediation strategies.

branches.title: Simulation and Experiential Learning
branches.definition: The use of simulation across the fidelity spectrum—from task trainers to high-fidelity mannequins to virtual reality—for skills acquisition, crisis management, and team training. Includes simulation center operations, scenario design, debriefing methods, and in-situ simulation.

sub_pillars.title: Assessment, Competency and Lifelong Learning
sub_pillars.definition: How anesthesia professionals are evaluated, credentialed, and maintained throughout their careers. This sub-pillar covers competency frameworks, workplace-based assessment, certification exams, continuing education requirements, self-assessment, and the systems that ensure providers remain current from initial training through retirement.

branches.title: Knowledge and Clinical Skills Assessment
branches.definition: Methods for evaluating cognitive knowledge and procedural skills including written examinations, OSCEs, oral boards, procedural checklists, and skills sign-offs. Covers exam design, psychometric principles, and standard-setting methods.
branches.lens: Measuring what learners know and can do

branches.title: Workplace-Based Assessment and Feedback
branches.definition: Assessment conducted during real clinical practice including direct observation (Mini-CEX, DOPS), case logs, 360° feedback, and structured feedback delivery. Covers rater training, bias mitigation, and formative assessment practices.
branches.lens: Evaluating performance in authentic clinical settings

branches.title: Competency Frameworks, Milestones and EPAs
branches.definition: The conceptual structures defining what anesthesia professionals must be able to do. Includes ACGME Milestones, Entrustable Professional Activities, competency committees, progression decisions, and holistic trainee evaluation.

branches.title: Certification, Recertification and Continuing Education
branches.definition: The systems ensuring initial and ongoing competence of practicing providers. Includes NBCRNA/ABA certification, maintenance of certification (MOCA, CPC), CME/CE requirements, self-assessment modules, and lifelong learning frameworks.

sub_pillars.title: Research, Evidence and Quality Science
sub_pillars.definition: The creation, synthesis, and application of knowledge to improve anesthesia practice. This sub-pillar covers research methodology (clinical trials, observational studies, qualitative research), evidence evaluation, guideline development, quality improvement science, registries, and the frameworks that translate evidence into practice change.

branches.title: Clinical Research Methodology
branches.definition: The design and conduct of research studies in anesthesia including randomized controlled trials, observational studies (cohort, case-control), qualitative methods, survey research, and the ethical/regulatory requirements (IRB, informed consent) governing human subjects research.
branches.lens: How to generate valid new knowledge

branches.title: Data Systems, Registries and Analytics
branches.definition: The infrastructure for collecting and analyzing anesthesia data at scale. Includes national registries (NACOR, MPOG), institutional databases, big data approaches, machine learning applications in research, and the use of data for benchmarking and outcomes research.

branches.title: Evidence Synthesis and Evaluation
branches.definition: Methods for appraising and combining existing research. Includes systematic review methodology, meta-analysis, network meta-analysis, evidence grading systems (GRADE, Oxford levels), and critical appraisal of literature quality.
branches.lens: Making sense of the existing evidence base

branches.title: Guideline Development and Knowledge Translation
branches.definition: The process of converting evidence into actionable recommendations and implementing them in practice. Includes consensus methods (Delphi, Nominal Group), guideline writing, knowledge translation frameworks (KTA, PARiHS), implementation science, and de-implementation of low-value practices.

branches.title: Quality Improvement Science and Safety
branches.definition: The science of systematically improving healthcare processes and outcomes. Includes QI methodologies (PDSA, Lean, Six Sigma), measurement and analytics (run charts, SPC), human factors engineering, safety culture, high-reliability concepts, and QI collaboratives.

sub_pillars.title: Innovation and Knowledge Dissemination
sub_pillars.definition: The frontier of anesthesia science and how knowledge is shared. This sub-pillar covers medical device and drug development, artificial intelligence and machine learning, digital health technologies, emerging scientific frontiers (consciousness, pharmacogenomics), scholarly publishing, scientific communication, and the dissemination of knowledge through traditional and digital channels.

branches.title: Medical Device and Drug Development
branches.definition: The innovation pipeline for new anesthesia technologies and therapeutics. Includes R&D processes, regulatory pathways (FDA 510(k), PMA, IND/NDA), clinical trial phases, intellectual property, technology transfer, and commercialization.
branches.lens: Bringing new technologies from concept to bedside

branches.title: Artificial Intelligence and Digital Health
branches.definition: Emerging computational and digital technologies in anesthesia. Includes machine learning and predictive analytics, clinical decision support, closed-loop systems, automation, telemedicine, mobile health apps, wearable sensors, and regulatory frameworks for AI-enabled devices.

branches.title: Emerging Scientific Frontiers
branches.definition: Novel areas of scientific inquiry relevant to anesthesia. Includes consciousness research, pharmacogenomics and precision medicine, chronobiology, neuroscience of anesthesia mechanisms, and translational science connecting basic research to clinical application.
branches.lens: The cutting edge of anesthesia science

branches.title: Scholarly Publishing and Peer Review
branches.definition: The formal systems for disseminating research findings. Includes peer review processes, journal publishing, open access models, preprint servers, authorship standards, publication ethics, reproducibility practices, and bibliometrics.
branches.lens: How research enters the scientific record

branches.title: Scientific Communication and Public Engagement
branches.definition: How anesthesia knowledge reaches diverse audiences beyond peer-reviewed publication. Includes conference presentations, digital scholarship (FOAMed, podcasts, blogs), social media, science communication to lay audiences, and altmetrics.
